articles.title: Q&A: The Activist Investor Who Shook Up the Board at ExxonMobil, on How—or if—it Changed the Company
articles.summary: This article features a Q&A with Charlie Penner, formerly of Engine No. 1, discussing the activist hedge fund's successful campaign against ExxonMobil. Penner reflects on the motivations behind the campaign to push Exxon towards better long-term capital allocation and climate planning, and assesses the company's changes a year later. He emphasizes that significant transformation will take time and highlights the interplay between investor activism, regulation, and a transition to a cleaner energy future.

articles.title: Chevron and Exxonmobil to explore lower carbon opportunities in Indonesia
articles.summary: U.S. energy giants Chevron and ExxonMobil have inked separate deals with Indonesian state energy company PT Pertamina to investigate various lower carbon business opportunities in Indonesia. These agreements focus on areas such as new geothermal technology, carbon offsets, carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), as well as lower carbon hydrogen development, aligning with Indonesia's net-zero ambitions. The collaborations aim to leverage each company's strengths to advance sustainable energy solutions and support Indonesia's energy independence.

articles.title: Tesla dumped by S&P ESG index as Musk calls label a ‘scam’
articles.summary: Tesla has been removed from the S&P 500 ESG Index due to concerns regarding working conditions, its handling of investigations into driver-assistance system deaths, and a lack of low-carbon strategy and business conduct codes. While S&P Dow Jones Indices noted Tesla's ESG score remained "fairly stable," it slipped against improving global peers. CEO Elon Musk subsequently criticized ESG as a "scam" and "fundamentally flawed," stating it has been "weaponized by phony social justice warriors."

articles.title: Cancer-causing gas emission spikes continue at refineries
articles.summary: A new report by the Environmental Integrity Project reveals that benzene emissions at many refineries, including Marathon Petroleum's Galveston Bay refinery, increased significantly from 2018 to 2021, exceeding EPA action levels. This highlights the persistent challenge for the EPA in controlling this dangerous pollutant linked to leukemia and other health issues. While some companies cite "atypical events" for the spikes, the EPA is investigating and environmental advocates are calling for stronger action.

articles.title: Global 2000: Berkshire Hathaway Takes Down JPMorgan As America’s Largest Company
articles.summary: Berkshire Hathaway has surpassed JPMorgan Chase to become America's largest public company in the Forbes Global 2000 list, driven by nearly $90 billion in profits. Despite global volatility, U.S. companies like Amazon and ExxonMobil showed significant growth, with Amazon rising to third in the U.S. and ExxonMobil rebounding strongly due to surging energy prices. The article highlights the resilience of top U.S. companies amid inflation and geopolitical challenges.

articles.title: Marathon is renewing its El Paso refinery's air permit. Here's how you can weigh in.
articles.summary: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) is holding a public meeting regarding Marathon Refinery's application to renew its air permit in El Paso. The meeting on May 24th will allow the public to comment on the permit, which outlines allowed air pollutant emissions for the refinery. Concerns have been raised about the TCEQ's new language access plan, as Spanish translations of key documents are not available, despite the refinery being located in a predominantly Hispanic, Spanish-speaking area.

articles.title: ICE launches nature-based carbon credit futures contract
articles.summary: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) has launched a nature-based solutions (NBS) carbon credit futures contract to bring price signals to the voluntary carbon market. This new contract, which traded at $11.25 per tonne for its December 2022 expiry, is designed to measure the carbon sequestration capabilities of nature. Companies like Shell have welcomed the initiative as a step towards greater transparency and scale in the voluntary carbon market, using such credits to compensate for emissions they cannot otherwise reduce.
